name: Overnight Apple Cinnamon French Toast
description: This is a great brunch recipe, it's perfect for large gatherings. A yummy bread casserole baked with sweet apple filling.

recipeInstructions.text: Grease a 9x13 inch baking pan. In a small bowl, stir together the  melted butter, brown sugar and cinnamon.

Spread the sugar mixture into the bottom of the prepared pan. Spread the apple pie filling evenly over the sugar mixture. Layer the bread slices on top of the filling, pressing down as you go.  In a medium bowl, beat the eggs with the milk and vanilla. Slowly pour this mixture over the bread, making sure that it is completely absorbed. Cover the pan with aluminum foil and refrigerate overnight.
In the morning, preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Place covered pan into the oven and bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for 60 to 75 minutes. When done remove from oven and turn on broiler.  Remove foil and drizzle maple syrup on top of the egg topping; broil for 2 minutes, or until the syrup begins to caramelize. Remove from the oven and let stand for 10 minutes, then cut into squares. Invert the pan onto a serving tray or baking sheet so the apple filling is on top. Serve hot.

review.reviewBody: I have made this recipe a couple of times and everyone has loved it!!! A couple of things I noticed is that I could only fit about 9 slices of bread in the pan before it started overflowing and it took 1 1/2 hours for mine to cook. I think next time I make it I will only use one can of apple pie filling and then I will be able to add more bread. Also make sure you spray the foil or it will stick.

This recipe was amazing.  I chose it because, unlike many of the other "make ahead" french toast recipes, it truly was 100% ready to go in the morning.  Just pop it in the oven.  When I made it I used one can of apples, and made sure it was apples and water only--no high fructose corn syrup--to keep the recipe from being over-the-top sweet.  The apples turned out so delicious, next time I probably will use two cans.  I used Pepperidge Farm cinnamon raisin bread, and baked for 90 minutes.  Everything else I kept exactly the same.  I used a cake pan and had no problems with it boiling over.  I didn't turn it upside down, and I thought it made a very nice presentation "as is" with the cinnamon swirl bread.  The bread wasn't incredibly crispy, as pan fried French toast can be, but it certainly wasn't gooey either.  I think using a slightly more substantial bread, like Italian or the cinnamon swirl, instead of white or French, makes a big difference.  I made it for a brunch for 11 people, and everyone absolutely raved about it. It was so incredibly simple--15 minutes the night before and you're done.  This will definitely become a staple in my house.  Thanks for a real keeper!  Note:  I made this again and didn't bake it as long.  Yuck!  Make sure you bake it long enough.

I have made this a fewtimes and everyone just loves it! Instead of the canned pie filling, I used fresh apples (3-6), peeled and thinly sliced. I tossed those with 1/2 cup melted butter (3/4 cup leaves a soppy, greasy mess at the bottom), 3/4 cup brown sugar, and 2-3 teaspoons cinnamon. I have always been able to fit eighteen slices of bread in my 9x13 pans (three layers of six). This bakes up perfectly in 70-75 minutes. Spraying the tin foil is an absolute MUST or it will stick. This recipe will be around our house for a long, long time. It's absolutely perfect!

The flavor of this french toast is really great, but you really need to make sure this is cooked completely through!  At 60 minutes, mine looked done, but was still very wet at the bottom of the bread layer.  We had to do a little improvising under the broiler, but all reviews were still very positive!  This is a keeper for sure... longer cook time and maybe a little less milk.  Yummy!
HUGE hit with my husband and everyone at the office.  Instead of usung canned apple pie filling, I sauteed my own in a little butter and maple syrup. This made it *perfect*!!!!

This was very easy to make and very good!  My husband loved it. I cut the recipe in half and baked it in a 8x8 pan.  Based on advise from others, I replaced 1/2 the milk with cream and cooked it for the full 75 minutes - it came out perfect and wasn't soggy at all.  To perfect this recipe, all I'd do is use just a little less brown sugar and syrup, so it's not quite as sweet.  Other than that, this recipe couldn't be any better!

Mmmm great recipe!  The only reason it did not receive 5 stars is because we did find it a little sweet for breakfast.  I will definitely make this dish again for brunch, but I think next time I will use McIntosh apples instead of apple pie filling, I think the brown sugar gives it enough sweetness.  I also want to mention that I cut this recipe in half and it turned out great!

Super easy, turns out great! A couple of suggestions... I've made this twice now, and it's been a hit both times!!! First time I made a 9x13 and could only fit 18 slices of bread, 2nd time I cut the recipe in half and used an 8x8 and fit about 10 pieces of bread. When it says to "press down", press down with some force, not  patting the bread. The first time I made it, I used the canned apple pie filling and it was good, but too sweet (and i LOVE sweet stuff). The 2nd time I peeled and sliced apples, put them in raw, and it turned out awesome! Both times I baked mine no less than an 1hr and20min.  I put a cookie sheet lined with tin foil under it to avoid bubbling over. I made sure to spread the egg mixture evenly over the bread w/ spatula, almost rubbing it in.  Spraying the tinfoil so it doesn't stick to the bread is helpful.  Also, I didn't invert it either time and it presented great and didn't seem to make a difference. People will be asking for the recipe guaranteed!

I just made this for Christmas brunch this morning and it was a hit! I kept it in the oven a little longer to make sure the bread was cooked all the way through! I already passed it along to my family members. Nothing but yummy!
Wonderful recipe.  I only had 1/2 cup of butter and it turned out just fine.  Thank you Sue!

Although I like traditional French Toast better, this was good and festive for a 
brunch I had.  My kids (both young and old) really liked it.  I used thick cut Texas style bread, so not as many slices used.  I also cut back on the sugar.  It was good reheated with vanilla ice cream on top!

This was a delicious breakfast treat!  Based on some other review comments, I made a couple changes to the recipe and got rave reviews when I brought it to a post-prom teen breakfast.  

Important:  Be sure to grease the aluminum foil you use to cover the casserole when baking or it sticks to the top layer.  I didn't remember to do that - not a huge deal though, because you flip it over to serve, so the torn part is hidden on the bottom of the dish.

Changes:  I used fresh Fuji apples (I think I used 3 large ones) peeled, cored, and sliced very thinly instead of canned apples because I wanted no additional sweetness to the brown sugar and maple syrup called for in the recipe.  I also used Pepperidge Farm's Cinnamon Swirl bread for the bread ingredient - very yummy!

The finished product was not at all mushy.

This was a very good recipe. It was very simple to put together and bake. It was a little to sweet for my taste buds but my kids loved it. I thought it should be a little crispier too but my oven could have played a part in that. Thank you

This turned out great.  The first time I made it I cut back on the sugar and used the applepie filling...it was great.  The second time I made it I still cut back on the amount of sugar but I used splenda.  I also made my own apples with fresh apples, a little brown suagar, butter ans mostly splenda.  I cooked them in a pan until tender and substituted thenm for the apple pie filling.  Very tasty and healthier.

This was VERY very good.  A nice Sunday brunch meal.  I used only 2/3 of the required brown sugar, and still found it pretty sweet.  I can't wait to try this with Challah bread (white bread doesnt really cut it for me).  I think I will definately try Rose Cook's suggestion about the peach and blueberry filling.

Made this recipe for Christmas morning and it was a big hit.  Everyone enjoyed it then and also in the following couple of days - very good reheated.  Both children and adults enjoyed it.  Really press the bread down into the apple pie filling, making sure that everything is nice and tight. This makes it much easier come serving time.
Delicious and oh so easy to prepare! Next time I will add pecans. OOOH LA LA!

I made this for a church breakfast - YUM. This is a keeper. Per a previous review, I did add some chopped pecans on top on the apples before pressing the bread down (by the way, I could only fit 18 slices -- 3 rows of six slices), and I added some chopped pecans on top. I was worried about inverting the pan - but it was a breeze.

This was delicious!!  All I got was raves.  I changed the servings to 18 - used a 11X15 dish.  I did not increase the brown sugar, in fact, I barely put in 1 cup.  Also, I kept the apples at 2 cans.  This was not too sweet.  I think one of the secrets to this recipe is to make sure it is cooked long enough.  I put it in for 75 minutes, covered.  Came out moist, not soggy.  I'll do this one again.

First, I didn't have apple pie filling, so I used tart thinly sliced apples (turned out to be the best part).  I personally liked this recipe, but my "wannabe food critic" husband thought it tasted uncooked (it was thoroughly done).  He didn't like the mushiness of the bread, but did think it tasted good.  Of course, he doesn't like his regular french toast to be "creamy" in the middle either.  Go figure.
This was good but the bread was quite soggy. It was more like bread pudding than French toast. I probably won't make it again.
I halved the recipe and made it in a bundt cake pan. It was yummy
I made this for a family reunion weekend and wished I had made more!  Easy to make, tastes incredible and everyone asked for a copy of the recipe.  It was the hit of the weekend.
I made a half batch for 4 in a 9 x 9 pan, with hazlenut bread.  Really yummy!  Just enough for 4 people.
I've made this more than once.  It's easy to do with company staying over.

I have prepared this according to a few other's suggestions.  I have used 1 1/2 loafs of peppridge farm cinnamon swirl bread torn into pieces, with 1 can of apple pie filling.  That was my only modification of this recipe and followed all directions otherwise accordingly.  It was very easy to make.  Tearing bread seemed to allow the egg mixture to soak well as it appeared just a little moist/wet before I covered it overnight.  I baked 1 hr, and then tried the broiler suggesting but my syrup didn't carmelize (probably because I used sugar free, didn't matter, everyone still loved it)  Also, when serving, I did not flip the dish over, everyone scooped from the 9x13 pampered chef stone I baked/served it in.  I am being asked to bring to future Easter brunches as everyone loved it.  Thanks for the recipe!  It's a keeper!
Very rich and wonderful!  Be careful....spills over in the oven quite a bit.  Use foil.
I brought this to work.  Everybody loved it and wanted the recipe.  It was gone in no time.  I will definitely make this again.  It was absolutely great!
This makes LOTS of servings and I'm not sure how well it will reheat if you wanted to have leftovers. It's really sweet!
So delicious!!!! A favorite for any special breakfast or brunch get-to-gether. I have prepared this recipes as directed with no substitutions and it has come out perfect every time!

Delicious!  With a bit of alteration on my part. I used 4  big Granny Smith apples. Peeled and sliced thin put in a saute pan with 1/2 c. brown sugar,1 c water and saute covered, stirring when necessary. When apples are done, add 1 tsp cornstarch that's been mixed with a little water to the apple mixture.  Cook until thickened like an apple pie would be. Had to used 21 slices of bread instead of 20 also. It was a big hit at Sunday morning golf!  Some women said "very rich--but delicious" while some of the men said, " I'll have another piece and I can't eat another bite I'm so full!"
The idea is delicious. When I make it, I cut up fresh apples and layer them over the butter/cinnamon mixture. I also leave out the syrup at the end. My whole family loves it.

This recipe is delicious! I didn't have time to make it the night before, so instead of pouring the egg mixture over the bread, I dipped each piece of bread in egg before layering it over the apples, and then poured the remaining egg mixture on top. I should have used a deeper dish, though, as it did bubble over; nonetheless, even my husband, who doesn't care for french toast, ate this up. So good....

This recipe is a winner. Easy to make and everyone loves it. I usually make it for work and its great for a large crowd. So nice to make ahead the night before and cook in the morning. And its not very expensive for how many servings it has. In fact making it tonight for our xmas party tomorrow. I will pair it with some creamy potatoe ham casserole & its a complete breakfast for a big crowd. Its fail proof.  try it

I brought this to a teacher breakfast at my school.  Although there were several other dishes there, mine was the hit of the breakfast!  Felt pretty good when those experienced homemakers were asking this rookie for recipes!

I made this for christmas brunch and it was sooo good....it was so simple to put together although i did not add all the bread( i used about 14 slices vs. 20)and used a little sugar and extra cinnomon to the pie filling and egg mixture...it was a great hit and great as leftovers.....thanks for sumitting this one Sue

This was so good!  I followed another reviewer's advice and used a loaf of Pepperidge Farm Cinnamon raisin bread instead of the plain bread.  Since this bread was slightly sweet, I did not add the maple syrup at the broiling stage, and we found it to be plenty sweet.  Everyone loved it, and we will have it again!  Thanks for the idea, Caljake!

I thought this was amazing and delicious - the kids didn't like it as much, but you can't win them all.  I used homemade chunky applesauce instead of the apple pie filling.  I don't think I'd use the canned filling only because it's so sweet and homemade applesauce is so easy to whip up - great recipe though!  Thanks!
I didn't have canned pie filling, so sauteed some sliced apples in a bit of maple syrup & butter... I used raisin bread & added some chunks of cream cheese in one layer.  Rave reviews!

Excellent Recipe! A little too sweet for our liking, but would make again and cut back on the sugar/syrup as well as only using one can of apple pie filling and combining that with fresh cut apples. Definitely use a deep 9x13 pan or lasagna dish!

We did encounter the same cooking problems as everyone else, but had to give it 5 stars for its deliciousness!  We baked it for the entire 75 minutes and it was a little soggy in the middle.  Next time we will bake it for 90 minutes.  We didn't want it too sweet so subsituted one freshly sliced, tart apple for the apple pie filling and it was awesome.  This is a new family favorite!

This was so GOOD!!! YUMMMMM. I run a daycare out of my home and all of the kids just licked their plates clean. My husband said it was GREAT make it again. I even had one child offer to have her mom buy all of the stuff to make it if I would make it again.. Thanks for the wonderful recipe.

Oh Boy!!!  This is the goldmine of french toast recipes!!!  I used two 10 inch corningware bake pans instead of the 9X13 pan which allowed for enough room.  I also used 16 slices of 12-grain bread which fit nicely in a double layer (8 slices per pan).  I had no apple pie filling on hand so I used 1/3 of the Apple Pie Filling Recipe on this site submitted by Terri (thanks for that great recipe too!).  The 12-grain bread gave an extra chewy crunch and next time I think I may add chopped walnuts in between the bread layers!  Thank you Sue!! :)
Super easy and the family seemed to like it. No rave reviews but it was so easy I would make it again.

This was good but very, very sweet.  It's better as a dessert than a breakfast meal.  I would definitely take purplesweetheart's recommendation and use fresh apples, like Granny Smith, instead of the canned.  Even the kids thought it was too sweet.
It took  longer to cook because I had too much in the pan. I think 1 can of apple pie filling would have been enough.
Yummy!!!  I didn't even invert this on to a platter and no one noticed as they were eating it so quickly.    Great breakfast treat!

Summary: a very good special occasion breakfast but makes too much for one pan.

I brought this to a breakfast casserole potluck and it was super popular, many people asked for the recipe. It was nice to have the variation with so many egg casseroles brought. 

I reduced both the bread and pie filling but my pan still overflowed all over my oven. Next time I will use one can of pie filling. With the bread, I will cover the pan once with slices, spread some egg,  cover the pan with another layer of bread, then egg and then be done. This should take less than one loaf of bread, I think. Oh, also, I left out the milk entirely and will probably do that again.

And I will put a jelly roll pan on a lower rack in the oven, just in case it spills over again.

This was the most WONDERFUL addition to a Baby Shower Brunch..I have had many requests for the recipe...If you don't feel comfortable turning out onto serving plate, it is just as impressive cut into pieces and served that way..YUM.
I used fresh apples instead of a canned pie filling. It was great! I took it to my MOPS meeting and had a request to put it on our Yahoo Group so they could all find it. Thanks!

Brought this to work and ended up printing out copies for many. It's a big crowd pleaser. I've done a 13x9 (1 can of apples 10-12 slices of bread), 8x8 (1/2 all ingredients 8 slices of bread, 1 can apples) and just recently a large catering pan ( 2 and a half cans of apples 20 slices of bread and double all the other ingredients) Same cooking time for all.  I have had success each time. The only thing is a bit of overflow in the oven with the 8x8 dish. Thanks CALJAKE!

I cut this recipe in half and baked it in an 8x8" glass pan.  I used only 8 pieces of bread and pre-dipped them in the french toast mixture before refrigerating overnight (as another reviewer suggested).  It baked for about 40 minutes.  I didn't broil it after putting on the syrup due to the glass pan.  Solid recipe!

This is a great recipie for brunch.  It makes a large amount, so the second time around I halved the recipie and it worked fine.  Also I use cinnamon raisin bread instead of white and it is excellent.
Thanks for the Great recipie
Very good and easy to make.  Perfect to make in advance.  Love the apples and cinnamon!

We enjoyed this last Christmas --Made it Christmas Eve to bake while opening presents.   On the sweet side try to lite apple pie filling or fresh tart apples. Leave uncovered for last 10 minutes or more to crisp up. yum

I absolutely loved this french toast.  I've never attempted any french toast before, but I don't know that I'll try another!  I made it exactly as stated with the exception of halving everything for an 8x8 pan and using the cinnamon swirled bread that someone recommended.  I also took everyone's recommendations to bake it the full 75 minutes.  My husband and I loved it!  I wouldn't change anything.  I'll definitely be making this again!
SO GOOD! SERVED FOR XMAS BRUNCH AND EVERYONE SAID IT WAS A "KEEPER" AND MAKE AGAIN.

I had 30 guests for brunch; everyone asked for the recipe. I used challah bread cubed; if I hadn't, the break wouldn't have soaked up enough of the batter. I soaked the cubes in the milk and egg mixture until they were soft. They absorbed it very well. I sprayed a metal large casserole pan very well with olive oil spray. It did not stick at all. It looked georgous when it came out of the oven. I baked it for 60 minutes as I live at 6500 ft. I did cut it in squares turning it over to the apple side on a decorative platter. My guests devoured it. I shall surely make this again, as will my many guests who took the recipe. Yetta from Albuquerque.

I made this for breakfast this morning and it was really good.  I used blueberry pie filling and halved the recipe.  I think next time though, I'd use fresh fruit - apples or blueberries or something - and skip the pie filling.  With the butter and sugar in the bottom you really really don't need all the sugary syrupy stuff that goes with pie filling.  If you must, you could likely bump up the brown sugar and butter if you're skipping the pie filling.  I think fresh apples would be way better.  Kids LOOOVED it as I made it though :)  With fresh fruit, I'd give it a 6  ;)

****UPDATE****
As I suspected, WAY nicer with fresh apples even with the skins left on.  I didn't even really up the butter and brown sugar in the bottom of the pan either, maybe just a smidge as I was measuring what was called for.  So good!

I made this for New Years Eve breakfast for my children and grandchildren.It was a hit.I used sugar free pie filling and one loaf of Pepperridge Farm Cinnamon Bread.Both my daughter and daughter in-law wanted recipe.They did not add the maple syrup and they baked it for 90 minutes.

I made it for Christmas morning.  I used the sugar free apple pie filling and cinnamon swirl bread.  It had just the right amount of sweetness for us.  I think next time I will add some nuts to the brown sugar mixutre.  Thanks for the keeper recipe!
Loved this! It came out so much better then expected, used fresh apples instead of canned and honey wheat bread, very delicious!
This was great! I modified it a bit though. I used 1 can of cherry pie filling (no sugar added), 1 cup of milk, 5 eggs, and 13 slices of whole wheat bread. My kids gobbled it up!

This was excellent.  Everyone loved it. I cut the recipe in half and only was able to fit in 8 pieces of bread as opposed to 10.  I used normal canned apple pie filling and it was so easy!  Only thing I didn't do was add the maple syrup at the end and we just scooped out of the pan instead of dumping the pan over.  Excellent.  Will definitely make again!
This was very good and easy. I will try fresh apples next time and more cinnamon but its really good they way it is. I just want to see if there is a difference using freash apples vs canned.
Family favorite...family requests this  Christmas, East, and any speci occasio.

I rarely review recipes but I had to make sure to comment on this.  This was awesome!  I made it for a football tailgate this morning and everyone LOVED it!  I used 1 can of apple pie filling and two fresh apples.  Also, I used Texas Toast like a few others mentioned...used 12 pieces, two layers right on top of each other.  It was scrumptious!

This was so delicious. I followed the recipe to a tee except I baked it right away. The advice was right to spray the aluminum foil cover because it rises. The whole family enjoyed it warm and cold. Delicious.
I don't know how this got 5 star rating. Besides that it didn't taste very good, it looked even worse. Sorry.

I make this every year, for either Thanksgiving or Christmas.  Simple to put together, and everyone loves it. I always use a dense bread, like country white, and cut it in cubes.  It makes it much easier to fit it all in the pan, and I think the milk mixture absorbs better.  I never bother adding the maple syrup, I don't think it needs it.

This was the 1st French Toast casserole recipe I have tried that didn't come out soggy.  I scaled the recipe down to 7.5 servings.  The kids wouldn't touch it, but they are extremely fussy.  Husband thought it was good.  I thought it was a bit sweet.  I did use half and half instead of milk as others have suggested.  I did make a mess flipping it though!!

I had high hopes for this one.  Instead of pouring the egg mixture of the bread, I dipped each piece and then placed it over the apples.  I discarded the remaining egg mixture in an attempt to keep my bread from turning soggy.  I removed the foil the last 15 minutes of baking and then broiled it for as long as possible without it burning.  The apple mixture tasted great.  The top of the bread was nice and crunchy, but again the rest of the bread was mushy.  This is my 3rd French Toast casserole to try.  I'm giving up and sticking to the old fashioned way of making french toast.
Maybe a little sweet but so worth it.

Made this for Superbowl Sunday Brunch and everyone LOVED it.  Only switch I made was using the thick texas toast bread instead of french.  I am wishing I had a deeper dish though because it bubbled out and over into my oven. (it needed cleaning anyway!)  Thanks for the yummy recipe!
Delicious!  It was very sweet, so I may adjust the recipe slightly next time, but my kids loved it!

I made this for christmas morning and was met with fabulous comments.  The only thing I would do differently is soak the bread prior to putting it in the baking dish.  I could not get the egg mixture to spread evenly.
This recipe was great!!! I did a double layer of bread, and it worked out great.  There were no left-overs.

I love this recipe and it has become a Christmas morning tradition in my family.  Both my mother and mother in law rave about it - the best thing is how easy it is to put together!  I only use 1 cup of milk to help eliminate sogginess, and I also use 1 1/2 cans of pie filling because I can't get it all to fit in the pan.  Spray the tin foil with some Pam before covering the pan; it will help prevent the bread from sticking during baking.
I had a leftover can of apple pie filling and was looking for a way to use it up.  I found this recipe and halved it.  It was very good and filling.
It was good but I found it too sweet. If I was to make it again, I would either skip the butter, sugar, etc step or else I would just use apples (i.e., not pie filling).

YUM!!!  Made this for a brunch and all of my guests went back for seconds.  Used only 1 can of no sugar added apple pie filling and 12 slices of bread in a 9x13 pan.  All other ingredients as listed.  Wonderful addition to a brunch!!!

The only thing I thought would be improved with this recipe, was to cut down on the sugar used. I have a sweet tooth, but this was even a little much for me. Next time I will make my own apple mixture (cooking them in butter, a touch of sugar and cinnamon) instead of the pie filling - which I thought added a lot of sugar and also made the texture of the apples softer than what I would've liked.  I think overall, it is a good recipe though. I will make minor adjustments for our tastes and use the recipe a lot.

The flavor was delicous. I love sweet so it worked for me, although it was soggy and i cooked it for the full amount of time. Maybe because i could only fit 12 slices of bread, and i used the full amount of egg. But it still tasted good soggy or not, although i wish it had a little crunch to it.
Disappointing. The bread was soggy. I used slices of Cuban bread. Will not make this again. The flavor was good enough to put up with or try to correct the sogginess.

I gave it 4 stars because even after baking for close to 2 hours and a trip to the broiler it still came out soggy. However, everyone requested it again so next time I'll just try a little thicker bread. I used bread that was medium dense from a local bakery and I think that was my problem. Very yummy!

I made a much smaller version of this breakfast ( a single versus a crowd version) but cutting the amounts of bread. And for the bread, use your favorite bread for this, don't limit yourself to plain white bread.

I made it with 3/4 c sugar and 1/2 c butter but I still didn't like it.  It didn't seem that appealing in the picture but I had already committed to it so I tried it anyway.  It doesn't look any better in person.  Maybe fresh apples might help.  I cooked mine for 1 hr 10 min and it wasn't soggy but it still doesn't taste wonderful like the other review claim.  It was ok for those who like sweet mush for breakfast or lunch.
I made this for Easter brunch and it was the BEST!!
This is delicious. Made it for a mother's day brunch and it was gobbled up.
So simple and so delicious! I added raisins and it turned out GREAT!

We loved this recipe! I made it with the Granny Smith apples instead of the apple pie filling and used egg substitute and skim milk.  I also used only a half cup of butter and brown sugar.  I was worried it would be too sweet.  It turned out PERFECT!
We loved it!  I used whole milk and just a little less than 1 1/2 cups and regular apples.

I love this recipe!  The reason for only four stars is I did make a few changes after reading the reviews.  I only used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup butter.  I also only used one can of apple pie filling.  I used cream in place of the milk and I used cinnamon raisin bread instead of white bread.  It was a great base recipe though and the result was so good!  This will be part of our Christmas morning breakfast for sure!

This was SO good!  I scaled down the recipe and actually made it for dinner one night.  I used no sugar added apple pie filling as well as sugar free maple syrup and it turned out really yummy.  It's been requested again since.

Very,very good,and so easy! I could not put in 20 slices, maybe 16, and I really pushed the bread down. I like the idea of trying it with raisin bread next time,and also using my own apple pie filling. I did have to bake it a little longer, but not much, because I let it sit out for an hour before baking it, and did take the foil off the last 10 minutes.
I made this recipe for a brunch/baby shower I hosted. It was so good, everyone loved it.

This is wonderful!  VERY sweet.  I used a deep 9x13 pan so it wouldn't cook out over the top of the pan.  I used thick sliced french bread, so used fewer slices. Think it would be great w/blueberry or peach pie filling too.  Thanks Sue for a great recipe.

I loved this recipe, Sue.  It was wonderful having Christmas breakfast sorted out the night before.  I baked the dish for 1 hour and 15 minutes whilst I went out for a run and relaxed.  

I followed the recipe as written but added some sultanas to the canned apple layer.  I used a double layer of white bread on top.  

My only other suggestion is that lining the pan with baking paper and also putting baking paper over the bread mix before the foil to prevent sticking.  I lost the top crust of my bread layer to the alfoil.

I did use the maple syrup glaze step as well.  I didn't find the recipe too sweet and my mum (who hates things too sweet) agreed with me.  The canned apples I used had no added sugar.

I served this with low fat vanilla icecream.

This is easy and delicious! Like others, I thinly sliced fresh apples and lightly sautéed them in a little bit of butter instead of using canned pie filling - they were perfect! I also used whole wheat bread (16 slices, fitting 8 to my pan and then adding a second layer of bread). I increased the eggs from 6 to 8 so that each serving had the equivalent of one whole egg. I baked it for 75 minutes to make sure it wasn't soggy. Adding real maple syrup and broiling for two minutes was a nice touch - really finished it off!
